Situation1: A passenger who booked through the app is waiting and urgently pressing for a quicker arrival.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, feeling the weight of the morning pressing in. My phone buzzed again—another message from the passenger who’d booked me through the app, asking if I was close. I could almost hear the impatience in their words. As a taxi driver, I prided myself on being reliable, getting people where they needed to go, fast and safe. But today, my mind was split. I had to swing by my apartment to grab my ID if I wanted to vote. It was the only window I had before my shift stretched into the night, and tomorrow’s schedule looked just as tight. The polling station would be open, but without my ID, I’d be turned away. I felt the pressure from both sides—my passenger counting on me to show up, my civic duty demanding I be prepared. My hands tightened on the steering wheel as I weighed the expectations, the minutes ticking by, knowing I couldn’t be in two places at once.
